d7740bff-1d0c-4ad6-ba4f-c93dea9132a5.summary: Memory as a source of knowledge
d7740bff-1d0c-4ad6-ba4f-c93dea9132a5.content: {Memory is a significant source of knowledge.}, {Empirical research can investigate the accuracy of memory.}

c1e6966a-b27b-48e6-ae67-b84bf4a88508.summary: The evolutionary basis of human understanding
c1e6966a-b27b-48e6-ae67-b84bf4a88508.content: {Human understanding has an evolutionary basis.}, {Empirical sciences like biology contribute insights into human cognition.}

a41cbc11-925e-44a7-b188-faae05f2657a.content: {Beliefs are influenced by available evidence.}, {Psychological studies can explore how evidence affects belief revision.}

48443079-c183-4e04-b814-d4dc3fbda9f2.summary: The integration of cognitive science with epistemology
48443079-c183-4e04-b814-d4dc3fbda9f2.content: {Cognitive science provides insights relevant to epistemological questions.}, {Empirical sciences inform theories of knowledge acquisition.}

0042cd30-a070-453a-9340-38bb2e5214e3.summary: The role of perception in distinguishing truth
0042cd30-a070-453a-9340-38bb2e5214e3.content: {Perception plays a key role in discerning truth.}, {Empirical research investigates how perception can lead to true beliefs.}

028db764-eb09-48e2-b4bb-bb0be70a1e11.summary: Testimony as an empirical source of knowledge
028db764-eb09-48e2-b4bb-bb0be70a1e11.content: {Testimony is a common source of knowledge.}, {Social sciences study the reliability of testimony.}

1a20d7b2-474e-4c7b-a0bb-9294fc61e366.summary: The necessity of belief for knowledge
1a20d7b2-474e-4c7b-a0bb-9294fc61e366.content: {Belief is a necessary condition for knowledge.}, {Empirical research can study patterns of belief.}

f513e698-a533-4a8f-afec-fd8f571d9ac1.summary: The brain's neural correlates of knowledge
f513e698-a533-4a8f-afec-fd8f571d9ac1.content: {Knowledge has neural correlates in the brain.}, {Neuroscientific research explores these neural patterns.}

c1c5ea6a-9ad7-47ee-87fd-069057c0e477.summary: The predictive power of scientific theories
c1c5ea6a-9ad7-47ee-87fd-069057c0e477.content: {Scientific theories often have predictive power.}, {Successful predictions strengthen theories' epistemic standing.}

52fd6ced-03f1-4d99-93d9-8016f320d770.content: {Human reasoning shows adaptability to new information.}, {Empirical research explores how reasoning adapts to updated evidence.}

3e03fd3b-a58f-4682-bdb4-e02f7a5ffc08.summary: Intuition as a subject of study in psychology
3e03fd3b-a58f-4682-bdb4-e02f7a5ffc08.content: {Intuition plays a role in knowledge acquisition.}, {Psychological sciences study the reliability of intuition.}

3bb7f13f-b5dd-4624-a47a-d1e3aef3bda1.content: {Confirmation bias affects belief systems.}, {Empirical studies can investigate the presence of confirmation bias.}

9ceff831-d4f8-451b-9a9f-df88043bd85a.summary: The role of falsifiability in knowledge claims
9ceff831-d4f8-451b-9a9f-df88043bd85a.content: {Falsifiability is a criterion for scientific knowledge claims.}, {Empirical methods test the falsifiability of hypotheses.}

b7feb655-cdc5-4870-b804-e3f229fac7f1.summary: The impact of environmental factors on cognition
b7feb655-cdc5-4870-b804-e3f229fac7f1.content: {Environmental factors influence cognitive processes.}, {Empirical studies examine how external conditions affect understanding.}

6c906bda-1084-41a3-b5b9-d5627730b9e8.content: {Beliefs can change based on new evidence}, {The likelihood of a belief being true can increase or decrease with evidence}, {Evidence can be evaluated probabilistically}

4a86c3fe-1a9c-42c5-82bd-bb5bb823b3ce.content: {Human reasoning often follows statistical patterns}, {Probabilities can guide rational decision-making}, {Statistical reasoning aids in updating beliefs}

bd97b4dd-24f2-43c8-845d-b04c87f49c73.content: {Knowledge often involves degrees of certainty}, {Uncertainty can be managed with probabilistic tools}, {Degrees of belief reflect uncertainty}

7969064c-1ac7-49ec-9038-8b1904442365.content: {Probabilistic models predict outcomes effectively}, {Predictions improve based on accumulating data}, {Good predictions enhance decision quality}

e5519b7e-e093-4692-9d82-f375b7d33de5.content: {Experience can be modeled probabilistically}, {Gradual belief adjustment occurs with new evidence}, {Probabilistic models reflect experiential learning}

28b8aa30-34a7-4bff-b86d-41cc183cee56.content: {Belief systems benefit from internal coherence}, {Probability aids in achieving coherent belief systems}, {Incoherent beliefs are rationally suspect}

a165c9fe-f64b-4e21-8315-2001f413cecf.content: {Belief strength varies among individuals}, {Probabilities can model subjective belief strength}, {Differential belief strengths affect consensus}

ae3a4baf-8ae4-4d10-a6c9-b126debc7fd4.content: {Scientific inquiry often uses probabilities}, {Scientific methods align with probabilistic reasoning}, {Empirical evidence informs belief adjustments}

0e8ebbc9-67fe-4ba1-b86c-f06c9be8b355.content: {Not all beliefs are absolute}, {Probability allows partial beliefs}, {Degrees of belief help in complex decision contexts}

a900d41d-b353-40d4-ac7f-0ed2b81af155.content: {Risk can be quantified probabilistically}, {Risk assessment is crucial in belief formation}, {Epistemic risk involves belief errors}

6a588427-f3e9-42b7-b0d6-04258a1d2f82.content: {Bayesian statistics models belief formation}, {Bayesian methods update beliefs with new data}, {Belief revision aligns with Bayesian principles}

57c61dfa-9733-46c4-9cc0-d477798f3260.content: {Uncertainty is pervasive in belief formation}, {Probability aids reasoning under uncertainty}, {Rational belief requires managing uncertainty}

9332539c-e72e-4a1f-b7e2-9731b3edd9cc.content: {Rational agents manage belief with probabilities}, {Rationality involves updating beliefs correctly}, {Probabilistic reasoning reflects rationality}

f8e611b5-9e29-4d94-8c2d-58f78d3973e4.content: {Rational agents can disagree based on probabilities}, {Different evidence leads to reasonable belief differences}, {Probabilistic beliefs permit disagreement}

da9b28cd-d10b-4af6-b5b9-dc85e75db8b9.content: {Belief change occurs incrementally}, {Gradual change aligns with probabilistic updates}, {Incremental belief change is often more rational}

5d5aa830-4d6a-493d-8f5c-c84f7c01a1db.summary: Consistency of justified beliefs with available evidence
5d5aa830-4d6a-493d-8f5c-c84f7c01a1db.content: {A belief is justified if and only if it is based on sufficient evidence}, {The availability of evidence is necessary for the justification of beliefs}

7740f8ea-aa48-44bb-88ec-48d0f656e169.content: {The rationality of a belief is determined by objective evidence}, {Personal biases should be excluded from belief evaluation}

a084b74e-5891-4114-bec4-22f54795eecf.content: {Individuals are responsible for forming beliefs based on available evidence}, {Ignoring evidence is considered epistemically irresponsible}

f94eebf8-1fea-4150-99e1-a9c274dda6f1.content: {Beliefs that align with the evidence are likely to be true}, {Evidence serves as a reliable indicator of truth}

9a33a884-1250-4ca3-bf48-ce360b245c70.content: {Beliefs formed without sufficient evidence risk being unwarranted}, {Guarding against unwarranted beliefs is an epistemic priority}

11a825e5-cc60-4dec-bd6b-95442ecf6ef2.content: {Belief formation should be guided by norms of evidence evaluation}, {Norms of evidence promote accurate understanding of reality}

ad19767b-c1ef-4fa1-a647-b04e78f3a9aa.content: {Evidence provides clarity in justification}, {Transparent justification aids in belief validation}

ed376b2c-3087-4373-ba3c-00d8124995c1.content: {Base beliefs on evidence to minimize error}, {Evaluating evidence reduces likelihood of false beliefs}

f7dd9eef-d3b5-468c-8598-c46a46083a2f.content: {Epistemic humility recognizes limits of evidence}, {Recognizing limits promotes open-mindedness in belief evaluation}

9d3bd2a3-66b4-48a9-9bd7-69bccae12904.content: {Intellectual integrity involves aligning beliefs with evidence}, {Prioritizing evidence over personal inclinations upholds integrity}

9445a51b-4c5b-4fd7-96e1-9eeb7f079261.summary: Practical concerns influence standards for knowledge
9445a51b-4c5b-4fd7-96e1-9eeb7f079261.content: {In high-stakes situations, there's greater scrutiny of evidence}, {There is an intuition that practical significance affects what we claim to know}

cd3a24f8-39a1-4b35-94e1-78ae2fb9ea8a.summary: Attention to detail varies with importance
cd3a24f8-39a1-4b35-94e1-78ae2fb9ea8a.content: {People pay closer attention to details when consequences are significant}, {Detailed consideration affects confidence in claims of knowledge}

a176169a-1e27-4107-bf64-bd10a059d7a2.content: {Decisions often force consideration of how much one truly knows}, {Uncertainty in decision-making shows varying standards for knowledge}

2dab882f-927f-4784-9a4f-67bbc8965463.content: {Mistakes have higher impact in significant scenarios}, {Awareness of consequence influences one’s confidence in knowledge claims}

b4128e8c-bb56-4b26-ba94-79c04ceae0e2.content: {Risk levels affect how evidence is evaluated}, {Heightened risk raises standards for claiming knowledge}

f124e19b-974d-4052-bbe3-bc9d9b8e318e.content: {Greater responsibility increases the need for certainty}, {Standards for knowledge adjust with perceived responsibility}

75b74d77-b5af-4d8b-8682-781666962ff0.content: {Practical circumstances alter how knowledge is evaluated}, {Epistemic evaluations are sensitive to the subject’s context}

2f7472ea-b89f-4248-ac37-302a5f6ba3d0.content: {Changes in context can alter what people claim to know}, {Contextual shifts result in variable knowledge standards}

7914efc7-446d-412d-8083-a94c940e7f83.content: {The stakes involved affect people's knowledge claims}, {More is required to claim knowledge when stakes are high}

30bd3e2a-c43b-447a-b669-68320105a365.summary: Belief certainty varies by outcome impact
30bd3e2a-c43b-447a-b669-68320105a365.content: {The perceived impact of being wrong influences belief certainty}, {Higher impacts raise the threshold for certainty in knowledge}

4010bf5a-bfba-4177-aa7c-15ce5b646f6f.summary: Can someone have justified true belief and still lack knowledge?
4010bf5a-bfba-4177-aa7c-15ce5b646f6f.content: {A person has a justified true belief that a proposition is true because of deceptive evidence that coincidentally aligns with the truth.}, {In a situation where the evidence is misleading but leads to true belief, we intuitively judge that the person does not have knowledge.}

414e40b2-0a5e-4431-959c-709266b96620.summary: Does the presence of lucky guesses challenge justified true belief as knowledge?
414e40b2-0a5e-4431-959c-709266b96620.content: {Imagine a situation where a person guesses the outcome of a random event correctly and believes it to be true.}, {The belief is true and the individual has some spurious justification, but intuitively we would not say the person knows the result simply due to a lucky guess.}

a7ed905a-c6ce-471e-b4e7-3614d3772c2d.summary: Can justified true belief arise from unreliable processes?
a7ed905a-c6ce-471e-b4e7-3614d3772c2d.content: {Consider a scenario where a person’s belief is formed by a process that is generally unreliable but happens to produce a true belief in this instance.}, {Although the belief is justified and true, intuitively this does not seem to constitute knowledge because of the general unreliability of the belief-forming process.}

a9200395-c2c3-49db-9145-3f7a56cf6434.summary: Can one have justified true belief without causation?
a9200395-c2c3-49db-9145-3f7a56cf6434.content: {Suppose there is a case where a person has a justified true belief that does not causally connect to the truth of the proposition.}, {A belief lacks the status of knowledge if the justification for believing does not cause the belief to be true, even when the belief is true and justified.}

657eba01-bceb-4df2-9728-9c4659c5ca18.summary: What about scenarios with multiple correct explanations?
657eba01-bceb-4df2-9728-9c4659c5ca18.content: {Consider a scenario where a person has a justified true belief, but the justification arises from multiple possible explanations, one of which makes the belief true.}, {The existence of multiple explanations dilutes the justification, intuitively suggesting a lack of knowledge despite the belief being true and justified.}

b2bab44f-e3fd-49e3-97b1-75fc001c1f5b.summary: Can temporal gaps between justification and truth affect knowledge?
b2bab44f-e3fd-49e3-97b1-75fc001c1f5b.content: {Imagine a belief that is justified and true, but the justification occurs long before the belief becomes true.}, {The temporal disconnect between justification and truth challenges our intuition that continuous justification is necessary for knowledge.}

511d0366-d165-4612-b152-ccc66c44d31b.summary: Does conflicting evidence undermine knowledge despite justified true belief?
511d0366-d165-4612-b152-ccc66c44d31b.content: {Suppose that a person has justified true belief, but there is significant overlooked or unavailable counter-evidence.}, {The presence of conflicting evidence intuitively suggests that the person lacks knowledge, as the belief appears less secure.}

a61bfc31-51f2-4ea5-9675-04774916c252.summary: Can a belief be produced by an unreliable process yet still count as knowledge?
a61bfc31-51f2-4ea5-9675-04774916c252.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person forms a true belief accidentally or through a flawed reasoning process. Intuitively, we would judge that knowledge is not present in this case.}, {A belief formed through an unreliable process should not be considered knowledge even if it is true, as it lacks a reliable foundation.}

e5807018-3c21-434d-ac8c-0549c75b6191.summary: Might a reliable process lead to true belief without constituting knowledge?
e5807018-3c21-434d-ac8c-0549c75b6191.content: {Consider a reliable cognitive process that produces a true belief by coincidence rather than understanding. Intuitively, we would judge that understanding is required for knowledge, not just reliability.}, {A reliable process might result in a true belief without the individual having an understanding, which challenges the notion that reliability alone is sufficient for knowledge.}

7a7c6e10-5fe7-4df4-a1c9-bca9c9b148a2.summary: How do we account for knowledge in cases of clairvoyance or extrasensory perception?
7a7c6e10-5fe7-4df4-a1c9-bca9c9b148a2.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person acquires a true belief through extrasensory means, which are deemed reliable. Intuitively, we would question whether this constitutes knowledge as it involves non-standard cognitive processes.}, {Reliabilism seems to suggest even unconventional processes like clairvoyance can yield knowledge if reliable, challenging our intuitive understanding of knowledge.}

5b139b8b-db1c-40dd-82f8-b627ecd84265.summary: Can knowledge exist in the absence of awareness or justification?
5b139b8b-db1c-40dd-82f8-b627ecd84265.content: {A case in which a person has a true belief produced by a reliable process but is unaware of this reliability seems to lack knowledge intuitively.}, {Intuition suggests awareness or understanding of why a belief is true is essential for knowledge, which reliabilism may neglect in emphasizing process reliability.}

14fa30f3-7365-42f1-9593-4c4ab149eb8a.summary: Are all reliable processes necessarily conducive to knowledge in misleading environments?
14fa30f3-7365-42f1-9593-4c4ab149eb8a.content: {Consider a scenario where environmental factors lead a reliable process to produce true beliefs only due to luck. Intuitively, we might judge these true beliefs are not instances of knowledge.}, {A process's reliability can be context-dependent, and external factors may misleadingly affect reliability, posing a challenge to reliabilism.}

72c3ff04-fcf7-4ddd-bc6c-5fb35354010a.summary: Does reliabilism account for the problem of forgotten evidence?
72c3ff04-fcf7-4ddd-bc6c-5fb35354010a.content: {Consider a situation where a person's true belief stems from forgotten evidence via a reliable process. Intuitively, this seems to lack the accountability required for knowledge.}, {A reliable process leading to true belief without memory of the evidence questions the sufficiency of reliabilism for defining knowledge.}

ecbba199-f65c-41b6-ab7d-7dcfbdca48a4.summary: Is process reliability sufficient to distinguish between knowledge and mere true belief?
ecbba199-f65c-41b6-ab7d-7dcfbdca48a4.content: {A situation in which a reliable process produces true belief and a distinct unreliable process does so by chance suggests that reliability alone does not differentiate knowledge from true belief.}, {Intuition may tell us that there is more to knowledge than process reliability, such as understanding or justification.}

aadf0102-f773-4d7d-b6ff-9e7e69d42931.summary: Does the failure to consider defeaters undermine reliabilism?
aadf0102-f773-4d7d-b6ff-9e7e69d42931.content: {Imagine a belief formed by a reliable process is challenged by new, undermining information. Intuitively, one may argue that retaining the belief without reassessment is not knowledge.}, {A reliable process should account for potential defeaters which, if neglected, could mean a failure in true knowledge acquisition.}

45e6a778-6621-421a-8d6c-bc391f072da5.summary: Is reliabilism too permissive by allowing non-epistemic processes as reliable?
45e6a778-6621-421a-8d6c-bc391f072da5.content: {Consider a case where a person forms a true belief through non-epistemic means, such as a lucky guess perceived as a reliable process. Intuitively, this should not be considered knowledge.}, {Reliabilism may wrongly categorize certain non-epistemic processes as reliable, thereby allowing them to count as sources of knowledge.}

ed77bb80-0ef1-4c2b-9a3f-4dd36be9e5cd.summary: Can reliabilism handle the lottery problem effectively?
ed77bb80-0ef1-4c2b-9a3f-4dd36be9e5cd.content: {In the case of a lottery, one's belief that their ticket will lose is reliably formed based on probability but is not knowledge, illustrating a disconnect between reliability and knowledge.}, {A belief about losing a fair lottery seems reliably formed, yet does not equate with knowledge, posing a challenge for reliabilism.}

389888b2-0663-4b76-855b-18c571201b8e.summary: Can knowledge exist without justification if the belief is true and no false lemma is involved?
389888b2-0663-4b76-855b-18c571201b8e.content: {Suppose a person believes a proposition purely based on intuition with no supporting evidence or reasoning. Intuitively, if this belief is true, it may seem like knowledge because no false belief contributes to it.}, {If a true belief formed without justification can be considered knowledge, then knowledge does not necessarily require justification.}, {It is implausible that a belief formed without any justification or reasoning process could be considered genuine knowledge.}

3c944a6d-5b89-49eb-ac4a-1db0a467dee4.summary: Can someone possess knowledge through a justified false belief that isn’t relied upon to reach a true conclusion?
3c944a6d-5b89-49eb-ac4a-1db0a467dee4.content: {Suppose a person believes that a proposition is true because of both true and false beliefs, but the false belief does not directly contribute to the conclusion. If the true belief leads to the correct reasoning, it may intuitively seem like knowledge.}, {If possession of knowledge requires the absence of any false belief in the process, then any false belief, whether directly relied upon or not, would invalidate knowledge.}, {A principle claims that knowledge can exist if false beliefs don’t affect the outcome of the reasoning process. If this principle is plausible, knowledge may not require a complete absence of false beliefs.}

82a8c72c-711e-4b9e-b397-a9ebb1816355.summary: Can knowledge exist in cases where evidence points to equally likely conflicting outcomes but eventually aligns with one true outcome by chance?
82a8c72c-711e-4b9e-b397-a9ebb1816355.content: {Suppose a person has evidence pointing equally to two conflicting propositions and forms a belief in one which happens to be true. The belief could be seen as correct by chance rather than by justified reasoning.}, {It is implausible that arriving at a true belief due to mere chance, when evidence supports multiple outcomes equally, constitutes knowledge.}, {A plausible principle is that knowledge distinguishes true beliefs by evidence or reliable processes, rather than arriving at truth through luck or chance.}

5ec71612-f2d8-4d13-bdc9-a0b395c1c696.summary: Is it possible to know through inferential knowledge if some inferences are inherently uncertain yet true by chance?
5ec71612-f2d8-4d13-bdc9-a0b395c1c696.content: {Suppose a belief results from a complex chain of inferences where some steps are inherently uncertain. If the conclusion is true, intuitively, it might still not seem like knowledge due to uncertainty in the steps.}, {A principle states that knowledge requires reliable inferential processes. A chain with uncertain steps violates this reliability, even if the conclusion is true by happenstance.}, {If inferential knowledge allows for chance reliability, then knowledge lacks the robustness typically required, making the requirements for knowledge less stringent.}

1c6dbef3-1458-4cfa-b1b9-4e6e62776df3.summary: Can knowledge exist without conscious awareness if all other conditions are met?
1c6dbef3-1458-4cfa-b1b9-4e6e62776df3.content: {Consider a case where a person’s subconscious reasoning leads to a true belief that is justified and uses no false lemmata, yet the person is consciously unaware of holding the belief. It intuitively seems questionable to call this knowledge.}, {Knowledge traditionally implies some conscious awareness or acknowledgment of the belief. If subconscious reasoning suffices, the conscious aspect may seem redundant.}, {If knowledge requires conscious awareness, subconscious beliefs, despite meeting other criteria, cannot be considered knowledge.}

2c23081f-ee05-4e32-b8c7-d72360e04cf2.summary: Does the involvement of an unknown defeater negate the claim of knowledge?
2c23081f-ee05-4e32-b8c7-d72360e04cf2.content: {Suppose a person believes a proposition that is true and justified, with no known false lemmas involved. An unknown defeater exists that would otherwise undermine the justification. Intuitively, it seems problematic to claim knowledge in such a scenario.}, {A principle holds that knowledge requires eliminating potential defeaters. If unknown defeaters exist, they could potentially nullify the justification required for knowledge.}, {If the possibility of unknown defeaters undermines knowledge, it suggests a higher standard of certainty for knowledge claims.}

e654746f-5f93-4385-b47f-4751aaea5e79.summary: Is a belief formed from unreliable but coincidentally true information considered knowledge?
e654746f-5f93-4385-b47f-4751aaea5e79.content: {Suppose a person forms a belief based on generally unreliable testimony, yet the specific information happens to be true. Intuitively, the genesis of this belief in unreliability makes its status as knowledge questionable.}, {A principle suggests that knowledge requires reliable sources or processes. Relying on consistently unreliable information, even if true in a particular case, challenges the reliability principle.}, {If knowledge can emerge from unreliable sources when the belief is true, the foundation of what constitutes reliable justification weakens considerably.}

7e0c94f1-d215-4102-a6bf-696e1a84cbee.summary: Does the notion of knowledge require a separation between evidence and belief, where evidence could mislead but still results in a true belief?
7e0c94f1-d215-4102-a6bf-696e1a84cbee.content: {Consider a situation where a person’s belief is formed directly by misleading evidence contrary to true facts, yet the belief aligns with those facts. Intuitively, this alignment seems accidental, questioning the belief as knowledge.}, {It is implausible for belief based on misleading evidence alone to constitute knowledge, as traditional notions expect a reflective correspondence with truth through evidence.}, {If misleading evidence can lead to knowledge, it conflicts with the expectation that beliefs should integrally follow from valid and truthful evidence.}

60c79692-53ce-4246-822d-d8caf679f635.summary: Is a causal connection necessary for knowledge?
60c79692-53ce-4246-822d-d8caf679f635.content: {There is a plausible principle that knowledge can be based on reliable processes and does not require a specific causal connection.}, {Suppose a person has a reliable belief-forming process that consistently leads to true beliefs without a direct causal link to the fact. Intuitively, this person seems to have knowledge.}

a4f0c0ab-b493-4ae1-9815-0f4088455be1.summary: Can beliefs caused by chance be knowledge?
a4f0c0ab-b493-4ae1-9815-0f4088455be1.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person believes there are ten coins in a jar because they randomly guessed it, and it turns out to be true. Intuitively, this does not seem to be a case of knowledge.}, {A case in which a belief is true due to sheer luck does not intuitively seem to provide knowledge even with a causal connection between the belief and the fact.}

6fed3199-f495-4f5a-870a-59ddfe859562.summary: What about knowledge without direct causation?
6fed3199-f495-4f5a-870a-59ddfe859562.content: {Suppose an individual deduces a true belief from another belief that is causally connected to reality, but there is no direct causal chain from the fact to the belief. Intuitively, the individual still seems to possess knowledge.}

734ca58c-154a-477f-804d-3105bffc2396.summary: Does the causal theory ignore justified false beliefs?
734ca58c-154a-477f-804d-3105bffc2396.content: {It is possible to have a justified false belief due to some interference in the causal chain. Intuitively, such a belief does not seem to qualify as knowledge despite the causal link.}, {Suppose a person has a justified belief based on a normally reliable source, but the belief is false due to an unforeseen factor. This belief would still have a causal connection yet lacks truth.}

bd293ee0-4e47-40a4-b673-661e5c163896.summary: Is the causal theory compatible with mathematical knowledge?
bd293ee0-4e47-40a4-b673-661e5c163896.content: {Mathematical knowledge involves a belief about abstract entities that do not have causal powers. Intuitively, mathematical truths can be known without causal connections to physical facts.}, {There is a plausible principle that abstract knowledge, such as in mathematics, does not require causal interactions with the subject matter.}

adb32a33-e372-488c-8bbe-afeb4ef73dbb.summary: Can coincidental causation be sufficient for knowledge?
adb32a33-e372-488c-8bbe-afeb4ef73dbb.content: {Consider a scenario where a belief is accidentally caused by an unrelated event that nonetheless reflects the fact. Intuitively, such accidental causation does not seem to confer knowledge.}, {Many beliefs may coincide with facts purely by chance and accidental causation, which intuitively do not constitute knowledge.}

bdb58e37-1233-4291-b4e0-cd2a2b12f05d.summary: Does the causal theory account for testimonial knowledge?
bdb58e37-1233-4291-b4e0-cd2a2b12f05d.content: {A belief formed through testimony lacks a direct causal connection between the knowledge claim and the fact itself. Intuitively, testimony is a legitimate source of knowledge.}, {Knowledge can be acquired through testimony that provides a causal connection to facts not directly accessible to the receiver.}

aa86915b-d305-4e7a-8514-943e1e089d65.summary: What about perception when causation is disrupted?
aa86915b-d305-4e7a-8514-943e1e089d65.content: {Suppose a person hallucinates yet accidentally forms a true belief about their environment due to an overlapping illusion. Intuitively, such a perception does not constitute knowledge, showing a need beyond causation.}

4e68fef0-089e-4f24-906d-ba429bb0dd93.summary: Does the theory handle knowledge of the future?
4e68fef0-089e-4f24-906d-ba429bb0dd93.content: {Future events cannot causally affect present beliefs due to the unidirectional nature of time, suggesting a lack of causal connection. Intuitively, foreknowledge, such as scientific predictions, seems to qualify as knowledge despite this limitation.}

e69ad1e3-28dc-4b1c-bc18-bbddeaa84d44.summary: How does the causal theory deal with memory?
e69ad1e3-28dc-4b1c-bc18-bbddeaa84d44.content: {Memory beliefs are about past events which no longer causally affect the believer. Intuitively, memory is a common source of knowledge without current causal interaction.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowledge from memory does not necessitate ongoing causal chains with the remembered events.}

7e82061a-e84f-418f-9955-9d8f32b62518.summary: Is the subjective experience overlooked by the causal theory?
7e82061a-e84f-418f-9955-9d8f32b62518.content: {Personal, subjective experiences provide knowledge of one's own mental states without a causal chain. Intuitively, introspective knowledge seems clear and does not fit the causal requirement.}, {Introspective knowledge of feelings or thoughts does not rely on external causal relations, yet these are considered knowledge.}

df4c0cd8-9be0-4480-acf0-0f166c9e754e.summary: Can a person with a true belief formed by luck have knowledge?
df4c0cd8-9be0-4480-acf0-0f166c9e754e.content: {Consider a scenario where a person forms a true belief about the location of a lost object by guessing. The belief is true, but the method of arriving at it is merely lucky.}, {Intuitively, we would not consider this person to have knowledge despite the belief being true.}

1827f791-79a6-4287-a639-cacb561765cd.summary: Can knowledge arise from unreliable belief-forming processes?
1827f791-79a6-4287-a639-cacb561765cd.content: {Suppose someone has a true belief formed by a fortune teller's prediction. The prediction happens to be accurate, but predicting in this way is generally unreliable.}, {It is implausible to say that such a method reliably yields knowledge, despite the belief being true.}

4b9f47da-94d3-4f0a-8fc4-97fa8c1b2c89.summary: Does intellectual virtue require an additional factor beyond truth and belief?
4b9f47da-94d3-4f0a-8fc4-97fa8c1b2c89.content: {There is a plausible principle that intellectual virtue implies reliability in forming true beliefs over false ones.}, {A true belief could be arrived at by a generally unreliable method, challenging the idea of arising from intellectual virtue.}

f8e918f0-4ec3-40ad-b870-70838acb98d6.summary: How does hindsight bias affect claims to knowledge?
f8e918f0-4ec3-40ad-b870-70838acb98d6.content: {Consider a situation where a person forms a true belief confirmed retrospectively after an event has occurred, such as a winning lottery number guessed without any basis.}, {Such retrospective confirmation does not intuitively seem to confer knowledge.}

68ec9a04-8ba5-4c27-a369-c65ab3cfe122.summary: Can knowledge exist independently of justification?
68ec9a04-8ba5-4c27-a369-c65ab3cfe122.content: {There is a plausible principle that justification is a necessary condition for knowledge.}, {Consider a person who forms a belief that happens to be true but for which no adequate justification can be provided.}, {It is implausible that such a belief qualifies as knowledge.}

9da0eb65-ab4c-4d3a-8cac-b30d9041aa02.summary: Is truth alone sufficient for knowledge with intellectual virtue?
9da0eb65-ab4c-4d3a-8cac-b30d9041aa02.content: {Suppose a person forms a true belief from a virtuous intellectual trait like open-mindedness, but the truth of the belief is verified by random happenstance.}, {The component of truth established through chance detracts from fulfilling the requirement of knowledge.}

9af27749-3620-4fd4-886d-e9559d228a24.summary: Can one possess knowledge with true belief rooted in irrational processes?
9af27749-3620-4fd4-886d-e9559d228a24.content: {Consider a scenario where a belief is achieved through blind faith without supportive evidence but is nonetheless true.}, {Such a scenario challenges whether intellectual virtue can exist without rational, evidence-based processes.}

00ed7f5e-6ab0-457f-a330-c4f6edef9ecc.summary: Is agreement among peers necessary for knowledge claims?
00ed7f5e-6ab0-457f-a330-c4f6edef9ecc.content: {There is a plausible principle that peer disagreement can undermine claims to know.}, {Suppose a person holds a true belief, yet all their equally informed peers disagree.}, {Intuitively, it challenges whether the person truly possesses knowledge.}

536df39a-e7ca-48fb-ae5e-03967c4800d1.summary: Do varying contexts affect the applicability of intellectual virtue in obtaining knowledge?
536df39a-e7ca-48fb-ae5e-03967c4800d1.content: {Imagine a case in which a person applies intellectual virtues in one context, arriving at truth, but fails in another, leading to a false belief.}, {Variability in success across contexts questions the consistent role of intellectual virtues in affirming knowledge.}

ea23e927-232f-4359-b39e-cebc8b120a50.summary: Does emotional influence invalidate the use of intellectual virtue in forming knowledge?
ea23e927-232f-4359-b39e-cebc8b120a50.content: {Consider a scenario where a person's strong emotions lead to a true belief about a friend's intentions which is accurate, yet the method lacks rational scrutiny.}, {Such emotion-driven processes seem inconsistent with the systematic reliability attributed to intellectual virtue.}

abe02378-f22c-4ee6-a331-5f1eb12d09d8.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person performs a task expertly and explains accurately why they did it despite verbally denying belief in their approach. In this scenario, intuitively we might judge that the person has knowledge.}, {It is implausible that a person must explicitly hold a belief about a proposition in order to have knowledge of it.}

0cf72e59-72e7-4f2e-b2fe-87b3fbf2d009.summary: Can truth always be required for knowledge?
0cf72e59-72e7-4f2e-b2fe-87b3fbf2d009.content: {It is implausible that knowledge requires truth because there are instances where a belief is justified and consistent with reality as we know it, yet turns out to be false due to unforeseen facts.}, {Consider a scenario in which a scientist holds a universally accepted theory that is later proven wrong. In this scenario, intuitively we might still want to say that the scientist had knowledge at the time.}

f4320929-b53e-4aa4-bbd3-095b249070e0.summary: Does the requirement of context for knowledge result in problematic relativism?
f4320929-b53e-4aa4-bbd3-095b249070e0.content: {It is implausible that knowledge depends entirely on context because this leads to relativism where multiple incompatible knowledge claims could all be true.}, {Suppose we have a case in which two individuals hold contradictory beliefs in different contexts but are both said to have knowledge. Intuitively, we either have to say that one lacks knowledge or reject contextual dependence.}

72ae8f89-956d-4e3e-9560-0eab81037079.summary: Is knowledge without context still recognizable as knowledge?
72ae8f89-956d-4e3e-9560-0eab81037079.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person knows a basic fact, such as the Earth is round, independent of any particular context. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that this knowledge does not require a specific context.}, {It is implausible that context has any necessary bearing on the knowledge of universally accepted facts.}

1229350a-85ef-4505-9cbf-03b6adb9d001.summary: Does context undermine the objectivity of knowledge?
1229350a-85ef-4505-9cbf-03b6adb9d001.content: {It is implausible that knowledge depends on context because this undermines the objectivity often associated with knowledge.}, {Suppose we have a case in which two experts in different fields interpret the same data differently due to contextual influence but both claim knowledge. Intuitively, we might think this challenges the notion that knowledge should be objective.}

f98fc6da-4dd5-4e32-94ad-9af026b61bf1.summary: Can belief be necessary for tacit or procedural knowledge?
f98fc6da-4dd5-4e32-94ad-9af026b61bf1.content: {Consider a scenario where an athlete or musician performs expertly without consciously believing in their method. Intuitively, we would judge they have knowledge of their craft.}, {It is implausible that having belief in a proposition is required for procedural knowledge, as knowledge might manifest in skillful action.}

ca2e64b0-97e0-4f32-bb03-a94cefea1f6a.summary: Is absolute truth required for justified belief?
ca2e64b0-97e0-4f32-bb03-a94cefea1f6a.content: {Consider a scenario where a juror has justified belief in a defendant's guilt based on evidence, but later evidence reveals a mistake. Intuitively, we might say the juror had knowledge at the time.}, {It is implausible that knowledge requires truth because justified beliefs might not always align with absolute truths due to new evidence or insights.}

bb1b207a-a9e2-4cbf-9227-5b5b963a6f9e.summary: Can contextual factors alter the truth conditions of knowledge?
bb1b207a-a9e2-4cbf-9227-5b5b963a6f9e.content: {Suppose we have a case in which the truth condition for knowing a fact shifts across different contexts, such as differing standards of evidence needed. Intuitively, this suggests a problem as two equivalent propositions would require differing conditions for knowledge.}, {It is implausible that context can legitimately alter the truth conditions for knowledge without leading to epistemic inconsistency.}

f786a380-f062-4cc1-8558-cafce23cc0cc.summary: Can knowledge be context-independent for eternal truths?
f786a380-f062-4cc1-8558-cafce23cc0cc.content: {Consider a scenario where a mathematician knows that two plus two equals four without reference to any context. Intuitively, we might judge this knowledge does not depend on context.}, {It is implausible that knowledge of eternal truths like mathematical truths requires any contextual consideration.}

378f86a0-51ff-4ed2-8ccf-51b07cc24105.summary: Can one have knowledge without belief?
378f86a0-51ff-4ed2-8ccf-51b07cc24105.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person acts correctly and effectively in an emergency because they possess accurate information but do not consciously believe that a particular fact is true. Intuitively, we might say that this person has knowledge in some sense because their actions reflect true information.}, {The claim that knowledge requires belief does not account for cases where individuals act on accurate information without consciously holding a belief in it. There can be situations where action guided by true information occurs without explicit belief.}

20e6f0eb-ea14-47b9-aa23-ba5b2bd7fbd3.summary: Is action a necessary component of knowledge?
20e6f0eb-ea14-47b9-aa23-ba5b2bd7fbd3.content: {Consider a scenario where a person possesses true, justified beliefs about a particular scientific theory but never has the opportunity to act on this information. Intuitively, such a person could still be said to possess knowledge of the theory since having justified, true beliefs is sufficient for understanding.}, {The connection to action might exclude forms of knowledge where action is irrelevant or impossible, challenging the necessity of practical implications in defining knowledge.}

c181cb71-a4b1-4a0d-9e01-540228537ee8.summary: Does practical benefit guarantee the truth of a belief?
c181cb71-a4b1-4a0d-9e01-540228537ee8.content: {Consider a case where a person believes in a superstition that brings them psychological comfort and leads to successful outcomes, resulting in a practically beneficial belief which is not necessarily true. Intuitively, practical benefit does not imply that the belief reflects truth, indicating that truth-conduciveness requires more than mere practical advantage.}, {The idea that a belief is knowledge if practically beneficial can lead to considering false beliefs knowledge, so long as they have beneficial outcomes, which challenges the truth-conducive component intended in the definition.}

906286a7-d5b2-4881-b7d3-49f3aebb309f.summary: Can truth-conduciveness align with false beliefs?
906286a7-d5b2-4881-b7d3-49f3aebb309f.content: {Consider a situation where a person holds a belief that consistently leads to successful outcomes but is actually false. Intuitively, we would not regard this false belief as genuine knowledge, since knowledge necessitates truth. The presence of false beliefs that produce successful actions highlights a discrepancy in identifying knowledge based merely on practical benefits and outcome success.}, {Instances where truth-conduciveness coincides with falsehood challenge the notion that truth-conducive beliefs are necessarily true, indicating that practical success does not guarantee truth.}

4d3fd1f3-7681-4dbf-94d3-e62edaa66126.summary: Can knowledge exist without practical outcomes?
4d3fd1f3-7681-4dbf-94d3-e62edaa66126.content: {Consider a person who possesses a deep understanding of ancient history, having justified true beliefs about events, but this knowledge has no direct impact on current actions or decisions. Intuitively, this person clearly possesses knowledge despite the lack of immediate practical application.}, {The requirement for knowledge to be connected to action overlooks the existence of purely theoretical or historical knowledge, which does not affect immediate actions or decisions but is nevertheless genuine knowledge.}

feb6d52d-5364-4ee9-b192-4e12ea87f2dd.summary: Do beneficial beliefs equate to truth-conducive knowledge?
feb6d52d-5364-4ee9-b192-4e12ea87f2dd.content: {Consider a belief in a motivational mantra that leads an individual to improved performance and success, yet the belief itself is not strictly true or based on fact. Intuitively, such successful or beneficial beliefs can be practically advantageous without corresponding to knowledge, implying a disconnect between beneficial outcomes and actual knowledge.}, {Beneficial outcomes arising from beliefs do not necessarily reflect knowledge if those beliefs lack a truth-conducive basis, indicating that practical benefit and truth-conduciveness might be independently variable.}

9c9f5427-f3c5-4d15-a26c-d19daf4843a5.summary: Can one be said to know something they do not believe?
9c9f5427-f3c5-4d15-a26c-d19daf4843a5.content: {Suppose a scenario where an individual has access to accurate information regarding an event, yet reports having no belief in the occurrence of the event due to lack of interest or trust. Intuitively, their access to all relevant and correct information might be interpreted as a form of knowledge.}, {Cases where individuals have true information despite lacking active belief suggest that knowledge can exist without firm belief, challenging the linkage between knowledge and belief.}

70d9e5aa-d3d3-4acf-854b-05ee6c1149b4.summary: Is belief inherently linked to practice for knowledge?
70d9e5aa-d3d3-4acf-854b-05ee6c1149b4.content: {Consider a person who holds a belief about a theoretical concept, such as a mathematical truth, which does not necessitate or result in any practical action. Intuitively, their belief in the concept constitutes mathematical knowledge irrespective of action.}, {The requirement for knowledge to influence action primarily fails to account for purely theoretical or abstract knowledge, where belief and understanding do not transition into an immediate practical realm.}

5ae217e5-3ae2-4573-80b2-3689bf3106e1.summary: Is practical benefit of a belief a marker of its truth?
5ae217e5-3ae2-4573-80b2-3689bf3106e1.content: {A person believes in a technique purportedly for health improvement with placebo effects that lead to perceived health benefits, yet the belief is based on unverified claims. Intuitively, despite its practical benefit, we would question the truthfulness of the belief.}, {The assumption that practical benefits imply truth overlooks scenarios where beneficial outcomes arise from beliefs not grounded in fact, suggesting that practical advantage cannot reliably substitute for truth.}

69511323-e8cb-4556-a14f-756432a5aa4d.summary: Does knowing always require actionable belief?
69511323-e8cb-4556-a14f-756432a5aa4d.content: {Imagine a researcher with detailed knowledge of obscure scientific data that never finds an opportunity to apply this knowledge practically. Intuitively, this person still retains a knowledgeable status independent of action.}, {Situations highlighting knowledge without practical application contest the dependency of knowledge on action, indicating that possessing information can qualify as knowledge without the necessity of practical execution.}

25ecffb6-c167-456b-b4c5-965f08e39c0a.content: {Knowledge requires belief.}, {There can be a belief that is false.}, {Knowledge requires truth.}

2583da44-8eae-4b49-976c-72c92e40bccc.summary: Can a set of coherent but false beliefs result in knowledge?
2583da44-8eae-4b49-976c-72c92e40bccc.content: {A set of beliefs can be coherent but entirely false.}, {Knowledge requires coherence among a set of beliefs.}, {Knowledge requires truth.}

ea66cb9f-6e5b-4cd2-88fc-3551caeb2540.content: {There is a plausible principle that a coherent set of beliefs should map onto reality.}, {This principle together with the possibility of a coherent yet false belief set suggests coherence alone cannot guarantee truth.}

3375fa5a-9bda-4323-8c4e-d1d3e2d33b97.content: {It is possible for an individual to know something based on a justified true belief without their broader belief set being coherent.}, {Knowledge requires coherence among a set of beliefs.}, {Knowledge requires truth.}

1ca628e7-5323-469e-8d7a-cbc206ece012.content: {Suppose there is a coherent set of beliefs that lacks any empirical or external justification.}, {Intuitively, we would not consider this sufficient for justification, raising issues for a coherence requirement.}

d4693dd2-f015-4054-9757-053b76a00f5b.summary: Can different coherent belief systems equally claim knowledge?
d4693dd2-f015-4054-9757-053b76a00f5b.content: {Consider two individuals with distinct but internally coherent belief systems about a historical event.}, {Intuitively, at most one can have knowledge if they contradict each other, questioning coherence as a guide to truth.}

f6f233f8-32d2-4719-afa9-f8506ab70aae.summary: Does coherence account for perceptual knowledge?
f6f233f8-32d2-4719-afa9-f8506ab70aae.content: {Perceptual knowledge often seems direct and immediate without coherence among a broader belief set being necessary.}, {Knowledge requires coherence among a set of beliefs.}

2cc4d384-a41c-4fef-9d32-288523e25136.summary: Can knowledge exist with mistaken coherence?
2cc4d384-a41c-4fef-9d32-288523e25136.content: {A person can mistakenly believe their set of beliefs is coherent when it is not.}, {Knowledge requires coherence among a set of beliefs.}

334f0531-98cd-4000-a486-ae84885adb4b.content: {New evidence may disrupt the coherence of a current set of beliefs but still provide knowledge.}, {Knowledge requires coherence among a set of beliefs.}

f633db1f-81ca-4a95-8925-ae9dfb77ea94.summary: Can isolated but true beliefs be knowledge?
f633db1f-81ca-4a95-8925-ae9dfb77ea94.content: {There can be a true belief that is not connected to any other beliefs or a larger belief system.}, {Knowledge requires coherence among a set of beliefs.}

6e65a45a-b4b0-46d3-bec3-e746865a05bf.summary: Must all beliefs in a set be true for knowledge?
6e65a45a-b4b0-46d3-bec3-e746865a05bf.content: {In a coherent belief set, some beliefs might be false while others are true.}, {Knowledge requires coherence among a set of beliefs and truth.}

e94ffe58-3148-489e-a46a-3dad7ba453d0.summary: Can coherence exist without mutual support?
e94ffe58-3148-489e-a46a-3dad7ba453d0.content: {Suppose a belief set is coherent without beliefs mutually supporting each other.}, {Coherent beliefs usually imply mutual support, leading to questions about how coherence is defined.}

9e684006-4376-4485-a8f1-768e88e83aae.summary: Does coherence rely on previous knowledge?
9e684006-4376-4485-a8f1-768e88e83aae.content: {Coherence often requires a foundational layer of beliefs, suggesting a dependence on prior knowledge.}, {Knowledge requires coherence among a set of beliefs.}

a48b8733-ee93-4845-8c42-d711ca380abf.summary: Does coherence require all relevant beliefs?
a48b8733-ee93-4845-8c42-d711ca380abf.content: {Consider a set of beliefs coherent internally but lacking relevant external connections.}, {Knowledge requires coherence among a set of beliefs and consideration of relevant beliefs.}

65610c03-106e-470c-b9fb-e93967effc83.content: {Coherence can vary from one individual to another based on the diversity of belief systems.}, {Knowledge requires coherence among a set of beliefs.}

95dd5f0f-99df-45f3-986a-f1b350ff60ec.summary: Does coherence exclude intuitively knowable truths?
95dd5f0f-99df-45f3-986a-f1b350ff60ec.content: {Some truths can be known through intuition without relying on belief coherence.}, {Knowledge requires coherence among a set of beliefs.}

02e1c855-df5e-452a-9354-2eeafc8357cb.summary: Can there be justified belief without requiring an infinite regress of reasons?
02e1c855-df5e-452a-9354-2eeafc8357cb.content: {There is a plausible principle that suggests a belief can be justified on the basis of evidential support without requiring an infinite regress.}, {Consider a scenario where a person forms a belief based on strong empirical evidence that does not derive from an infinite chain of reasons. In such cases, intuitively, we judge the belief to be justified.}

6e13af77-56b9-4dab-9614-6eac8ea406c6.summary: Is the requirement for an infinite chain of reasons practically feasible for justification?
6e13af77-56b9-4dab-9614-6eac8ea406c6.content: {It is implausible that human cognitive capacities allow for the apprehension and management of infinite chains of reasoning.}, {Suppose we have a case where an individual must justify a belief through an endless sequence of reasons. Intuitively, such a demand seems impossible given cognitive limitations.}

8a0aa8f4-b26b-4ad9-ba90-696d13e9c9e3.summary: Do ordinary instances of knowledge imply the existence of infinite chains of reasons?
8a0aa8f4-b26b-4ad9-ba90-696d13e9c9e3.content: {Consider a scenario in which someone knows that the sun is shining by seeing it is daylight. We do not typically require them to justify this belief with an infinite rationale.}, {A plausible principle is that ordinary instances of knowledge, which are generally accepted, do not involve such elaborate inferential structures.}

7cb96beb-633d-490c-9a5f-2e7cd4f206d2.summary: Does the regress problem have a stopping point allowing for finite justification?
7cb96beb-633d-490c-9a5f-2e7cd4f206d2.content: {There is a plausible principle maintaining that beliefs can be justified through foundational reasons that do not require further support, thereby stopping the regress.}, {Consider a belief that is evident through immediate experience or perception, where additional reasoning does not augment its justification.}

747556e4-4435-4784-b2dc-3426aef539a4.summary: Could finite chains of reasons be sufficient for justification?
747556e4-4435-4784-b2dc-3426aef539a4.content: {Suppose we have a justified belief obtained through a series of finite reasons. Intuitively, such a belief does not appear less justified merely because the reasons are not infinite.}, {It is implausible to think that an infinite extension is necessary when a finite chain effectively supports a belief.}

1a315406-7071-4ffe-9cc2-43073cc62489.summary: Is it meaningful to claim actual human knowledge meets the criterion of infinitism?
1a315406-7071-4ffe-9cc2-43073cc62489.content: {It is implausible that actual human knowledge can be effectively described or manifested through an infinitely long chain of reasons.}, {Consider a scenario where practical knowledge is attained, like cooking a recipe learned from experience, which lacks an obvious infinite chain of reasons yet seems competently justified.}

37fd0649-b8ee-4523-85ce-aa0011e5b48f.summary: Can infinite justification be considered necessary when many justified beliefs lack explicit reasoning?
37fd0649-b8ee-4523-85ce-aa0011e5b48f.content: {Many justified beliefs are held without explicit, conscious reasoning, such as rudimentary perceptual beliefs.}, {There is a plausible principle that not all justified beliefs require articulated justifications, thus challenging the necessity of an infinite chain.}

ac5cc459-9423-446d-a797-7622c37e7de2.summary: Can empirical science provide justification through finite explanatory chains?
ac5cc459-9423-446d-a797-7622c37e7de2.content: {Consider scientific explanations that provide justification through empirical evidence and logical inference, typically expressed economically rather than with infinite reasoning.}, {A plausible principle in science is that simpler, explanatory models are preferable and adequately justified, contrasting with infinite recession.}

7647ca2b-ba34-4b42-a8b2-a374aad792d2.summary: Does the demand for infinite justifications introduce unnecessary complexity?
7647ca2b-ba34-4b42-a8b2-a374aad792d2.content: {It is implausible that the complexity introduced by requiring infinite chains genuinely enhances justification of a belief.}, {Consider a situation where an explanation suffices to clarify a belief yet is challenged by an unwieldly and endless demand for reasons, seeming more obstructive than clarifying.}

d6e57845-f4bf-4e98-98a8-a9e0fb0fbfca.summary: Does experience-based learning support the need for infinite reasoning?
d6e57845-f4bf-4e98-98a8-a9e0fb0fbfca.content: {Consider a scenario where skill is acquired through experience and practice, resulting in justified knowledge about the skill.}, {A plausible principle holds that experiential learning involves direct knowledge acquisition rather than an infinite cascade of reasoning, challenging infinitism in such contexts.}

9b511ab9-7aab-4df7-a2de-287364e92b06.summary: Can knowledge exist without belief if there is truth and justification?
9b511ab9-7aab-4df7-a2de-287364e92b06.content: {It is possible for an individual to know something to be true without explicitly believing it.}, {Knowledge can be derived from external evidence without necessitating belief in those claims.}, {A scenario can be imagined where a person accurately describes a fact they call knowledge, even if they lack belief in it.}

3abf3b85-b9ca-43ee-ba00-d3c36412848b.summary: Is it necessary for knowledge to be based on self-justified beliefs?
3abf3b85-b9ca-43ee-ba00-d3c36412848b.content: {Many beliefs can be justified through an interconnected web, rather than being self-justified or evident.}, {In some philosophical systems, beliefs that are justified through coherence with other beliefs are considered sufficient for knowledge.}, {There are examples of belief systems where no belief stands alone as self-justified, yet the system still produces knowledge.}

b35a64de-db14-49ad-aaeb-15208c49a8a6.summary: Can knowledge arise from sources other than basic beliefs?
b35a64de-db14-49ad-aaeb-15208c49a8a6.content: {Knowledge can emerge from derivative beliefs that gain justification through context and experience.}, {A theoretical approach can demonstrate that some beliefs lead to knowledge through inferential means rather than being foundational.}, {In some situations, people rely on beliefs formed through empirical methods that are not initially basic but later accepted as knowledge.}

0b70cb81-f399-4f6b-aa35-a292b8e2a152.summary: What if truth and belief in a false context lead to knowledge?
0b70cb81-f399-4f6b-aa35-a292b8e2a152.content: {Consider a situation where a belief accurately reflects reality but is formed in a misleading context, raising doubt about its validity.}, {Several examples illustrate beliefs accidentally aligning with truth, prompting debate on their legitimacy as knowledge.}, {It is logically possible for a belief formed under false pretenses to accidentally be true, questioning its status as knowledge.}

656ed2d0-6cf7-4d77-834b-b08f514cd314.summary: Does perceptual experience always provide self-justified beliefs?
656ed2d0-6cf7-4d77-834b-b08f514cd314.content: {Perceptual experiences are prone to illusion and error, challenging the notion they always provide self-evident beliefs.}, {There is empirical evidence that sensory perceptions can be influenced and manipulated, raising questions about their reliability as foundations for knowledge.}, {Instances of perceptual error, such as optical illusions, suggest sensory information does not always lead to justified true beliefs.}

9297ecff-72c8-447e-ae17-0103edbfe89f.summary: Can false beliefs still contribute to the acquisition of knowledge?
9297ecff-72c8-447e-ae17-0103edbfe89f.content: {A framework exists where false beliefs lead to corrections that improve understanding, suggesting a non-foundational route to knowledge.}, {Counterexamples highlight that false beliefs may prompt inquiry that eventually leads to true knowledge, questioning their exclusion from contributing to knowledge.}, {Philosophers have suggested that examining and refuting false beliefs is a crucial pathway to substantive knowledge.}

52e9a8b0-8dea-44c8-bbc2-d488634e11a3.summary: Is it possible to have knowledge that is not truth-dependent?
52e9a8b0-8dea-44c8-bbc2-d488634e11a3.content: {There are conceptions of knowledge that emphasize utility or coherence over truth, challenging the necessity of truth for knowledge claims.}, {In certain philosophical angles, knowledge is seen as justified belief that effectively navigates the world, regardless of strict truth correspondence.}, {Knowledge systems that prioritize practical outcomes over truth offer a different lens to view the relationship between belief, justification, and knowledge.}

fa9ae960-3e32-41a1-a4cb-67004adb889f.summary: Could foundational beliefs themselves be subject to skepticism?
fa9ae960-3e32-41a1-a4cb-67004adb889f.content: {A belief regarded as foundational can still be questioned through skeptical inquiry, undermining its status as self-justified.}, {Examples of supposed foundational beliefs being reconsidered upon further investigation suggest their vulnerability to doubt.}, {Philosophical arguments present scenarios where no belief is immune to philosophical skepticism, eroding the confidence in foundational beliefs.}

2071a60f-df6f-44f5-9afd-ab01f70e4414.summary: How does memory impact the judgment of basic beliefs as self-justified?
2071a60f-df6f-44f5-9afd-ab01f70e4414.content: {Memory's fallibility casts doubt on the reliability of recalling basic beliefs as truly self-justified or evident.}, {Inconsistent recollections illustrate the problem of considering memory a secure source of foundational belief.}, {Philosophical debates on memory emphasize its ability to distort knowledge, challenging its foundational reliability.}

5f93cf84-297d-4e20-8aa1-2924bfffbad2.summary: Is certainty required for knowledge to be self-justifying?
5f93cf84-297d-4e20-8aa1-2924bfffbad2.content: {Certainty is often unattainable for many beliefs considered knowledge, suggesting self-justification does not imply absolute certainty.}, {The quest for absolute certainty in knowledge has historically led to philosophical dead ends, implying practical rather than certain justification might suffice.}, {In practical contexts, knowledge operates with degrees of justification rather than unwavering certainty, adjusting the notion of self-evident knowledge.}

35d93537-e2ab-4171-a501-5a177726de76.summary: Does knowledge require belief in all cases?
35d93537-e2ab-4171-a501-5a177726de76.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person gains knowledge through unconscious perception but holds no conscious belief. Intuitively, we would judge that the person possesses knowledge without belief.}, {It is implausible to assert that knowledge requires a conscious belief if the person internally processes the information accurately.}

b0892c8b-0f06-4f14-8bab-b0c03d17f9ee.summary: Can knowledge be true by accident?
b0892c8b-0f06-4f14-8bab-b0c03d17f9ee.content: {Consider a case where a person believes a falsehood, but coincidentally the belief turns out to be true due to unrelated factors they are unaware of. Intuitively, we would not say the person has knowledge, even though their belief is true.}, {There is a plausible principle that a belief must be true due to the reasons for which it was believed for it to constitute knowledge. This principle entails that mere truth is insufficient for knowledge.}

5820395a-9d86-4625-a579-b0d6b2cd155d.summary: Does subjective awareness play a role in knowledge?
5820395a-9d86-4625-a579-b0d6b2cd155d.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person has access to all truthful information but remains unaware of its implications due to a lack of subjective awareness. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person does not have knowledge or admit subjective awareness influences knowledge.}, {It is implausible that knowledge fully depends on external factors if subjective awareness is required to process and utilize the information.}

dddfe4bc-993e-4851-9783-7d04bfdc50ca.summary: Is it possible to have knowledge without external justification?
dddfe4bc-993e-4851-9783-7d04bfdc50ca.content: {Consider a scenario in which an individual has a strong and justified internal conviction but lacks external evidence or support. Intuitively, we would judge that internal conviction alone does not constitute knowledge.}, {There is a plausible principle that external justification is necessary to convert justified true belief into knowledge. This principle suggests knowledge relies on more than subjective internal states.}

4cb03d32-2157-44dc-8f7a-927ba78825e0.summary: Can knowledge exist independently of truth?
4cb03d32-2157-44dc-8f7a-927ba78825e0.content: {Suppose we have a case where a person is completely certain about a belief that is false but aligns with all available evidence. Intuitively, we either have to say that certainty does not equate to knowledge or deny that truth is necessary for knowledge.}, {It is implausible to consider the possibility of knowledge existing without correspondence to an objective truth.}

b01326ca-21e8-4aa9-b693-8cb5c0aa5ed5.summary: Does unconscious knowledge challenge the belief requirement in knowledge?
b01326ca-21e8-4aa9-b693-8cb5c0aa5ed5.content: {Consider a scenario where a person correctly navigates an environment through unconscious learning but does not consciously believe in or understand the learned information. Intuitively, we would judge that the person has knowledge despite lacking conscious belief.}, {It is implausible to reject unconscious knowledge, as it reflects accurate internal processing of environmental cues.}

56d0fbc5-4928-45de-a85e-1466e6eaa5d2.summary: Is external correspondence sufficient for truth in knowledge?
56d0fbc5-4928-45de-a85e-1466e6eaa5d2.content: {A case in which a belief aligns randomly with external reality without any logical connection appearing to make the belief true seems insufficient for knowledge.}, {There is a plausible principle that truth requires an explanatory relationship between a belief and the facts in order to constitute knowledge. This principle challenges the idea that alignment alone can define truth in knowledge.}

b181d694-f221-4c6d-8c05-f5c922497970.summary: Can external factors undermine subjective certainty in knowledge?
b181d694-f221-4c6d-8c05-f5c922497970.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is completely subjectively certain they have knowledge due to an internal understanding but is later undermined by unknown external factors. Intuitively, we would judge that this certainty is misaligned with the nature of knowledge.}, {It is implausible to assert that subjective certainty alone, even when authentic, is definitive of true knowledge.}

ccee865a-93e5-4803-b447-abe83ec1e85b.summary: Is it plausible for knowledge to depend solely on factors outside personal control?
ccee865a-93e5-4803-b447-abe83ec1e85b.content: {Suppose we have a case where a person has made no effort to understand or believe something, yet what they believe coincidentally aligns with the truth due to external factors. Intuitively, we either have to say that personal agency matters in knowledge acquisition or deny that control is relevant to knowledge.}, {It is implausible that individuals gain knowledge purely by external happenstance without personal contribution or understanding.}

9ba39ba8-7a03-4456-bff1-20eb26669fe6.content: {It is plausible that someone can act as if they know something without believing it.}, {A case where someone convincingly fakes belief in a fact suggests that belief is not necessary for knowledge.}, {This indicates that belief may not be a necessary component for knowledge.}

945523b2-505a-45f9-a0b0-9aff51cc4b5c.summary: Is truth an absolute requirement for knowledge?
945523b2-505a-45f9-a0b0-9aff51cc4b5c.content: {In some cases, people act with certainty based on false information, suggesting that knowledge can exist without truth.}, {A situation where a person makes a successful prediction based on a false premise can challenge the need for truth.}, {Such examples suggest that truth may not be a strict requirement for possessing knowledge.}

e17db057-12a5-4aac-93a4-54b2fc0866d9.summary: Can justification be inaccessible and still constitute knowledge?
e17db057-12a5-4aac-93a4-54b2fc0866d9.content: {There are instances where individuals possess knowledge without being consciously aware of their justification.}, {People sometimes intuitively know things without articulating the reasoning, challenging the necessity of accessible justification.}, {This suggests that justification could be an unconscious process.}

afca9b9f-619e-45aa-9625-9527f4c29fb7.summary: Can knowledge be possible without conscious access to justification?
afca9b9f-619e-45aa-9625-9527f4c29fb7.content: {Children and animals often seem to act on reliable knowledge without explicit reasoning.}, {A child's skillful navigation of a familiar environment without conscious reasoning questions the need for accessible justification.}, {Justification may exist without the individual's awareness.}

72b36cc9-5b6e-4157-b212-db6300c1ad5f.summary: Could an external source of truth provide knowledge without direct justification?
72b36cc9-5b6e-4157-b212-db6300c1ad5f.content: {In certain situations, people receive expert knowledge without understanding the justification themselves.}, {A person knowing the Earth orbits the Sun without understanding the physics challenges the need for personal justification access.}, {This points to external justification being sufficient for knowledge.}

859d2e4d-c5aa-4fa1-83f4-94cbca357094.summary: Is internal access to justification necessary when external validation is available?
859d2e4d-c5aa-4fa1-83f4-94cbca357094.content: {In scenarios where an external authority verifies a fact, individuals may possess knowledge without internal justification.}, {Relying on verified scientific facts without understanding them exemplifies this challenge to internal justification.}, {Justification can be valid even if not internally accessible.}

dc7cba60-e998-431a-9ca4-55c2de8387ac.summary: Does the presence of justified true belief without knowledge challenge the Defeasibility Theory?
dc7cba60-e998-431a-9ca4-55c2de8387ac.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person Mary has a justified belief that the barn she sees is real and it is indeed true. However, unbeknownst to Mary, she is in an area full of fake barn facades.}, {In such a scenario, it is implausible to say that Mary has knowledge even though she has a justified true belief.}

4f000915-e201-48f9-ab7a-7e4b2eb6b036.summary: Can a case of knowledge creation through luck undermine the persistence of knowledge suggested by Defeasibility Theory?
4f000915-e201-48f9-ab7a-7e4b2eb6b036.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person John forms a belief that his coworker will be late, based on the coworker's typical tardiness. Coincidentally, the coworker is late due to an unexpected traffic jam.}, {Intuitively, even though John's belief is true and persists, it seems implausible to claim John has knowledge due to the role of luck.}

ee065081-be91-45d3-94e5-b0d6ee754872.summary: What happens if a belief's justification is later invalidated, yet the belief remains true?
ee065081-be91-45d3-94e5-b0d6ee754872.content: {There is a plausible principle that if the justification for a belief is invalidated, the knowledge claim should be reconsidered.}, {Consider a scenario where Sarah believes it will rain because of a forecast, but the forecast was a computer error. It indeed rains.}, {It is implausible to maintain Sarah had knowledge oblivious to the initial justification's flaw even if it remains true.}

daa7cbb3-4bbb-40c7-8185-2062d8097912.summary: Does the Defeasibility Theory account for the Gettier problem adequately?
daa7cbb3-4bbb-40c7-8185-2062d8097912.content: {Consider a scenario in which Tom believes a colleague owns a Ford due to seeing them drive an old Ford often. Meanwhile, unknown to Tom, they had sold it and now rent another. By chance, they decide to rent another Ford that week.}, {Intuitively, Tom cannot claim knowledge, despite his justified true belief, because the belief's truth is accidental, highlighting a gap in the Defeasibility Theory.}

64c0e5f1-206f-4e31-87b7-5507490afac6.summary: How does the Defeasibility Theory handle beliefs that are correct but lack basis?
64c0e5f1-206f-4e31-87b7-5507490afac6.content: {Suppose we have a case where Laura believes her friend passed an exam without any evidence and the friend indeed passed.}, {It seems implausible to ascribe knowledge to Laura in this instance merely because her belief was correct, challenging the notion that belief and truth are sufficient absent a defeater.}

787bf621-fa3f-469a-b0c4-9e546aa110c7.summary: Does Defeasibility Theory address scenarios where perception fails unexpectedly?
787bf621-fa3f-469a-b0c4-9e546aa110c7.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person hears what sounds like rain on a window, forming a belief it is raining. Unknown to them, it is a faulty sprinkler system. However, it is in fact raining.}, {The individual in this scenario lacks more than a true belief due to coincidental factors, indicating knowledge requirements are subtler than suggested by Defeasibility Theory.}

3aad95cc-13c5-4fc2-bb6c-2264dc8a88a2.summary: Can a defeater arise from external circumstances unknown to the believer?
3aad95cc-13c5-4fc2-bb6c-2264dc8a88a2.content: {There is a plausible principle that knowledge should incorporate an awareness of potential defeaters.}, {Suppose Emily confidently believes her email was sent, based on her actions. However, internet issues she is unaware of render this untrue.}, {Emily's belief, true by chance later, highlights knowledge is not as secure as proposed given unawareness of potential defeaters.}

3f9dc3f1-0e8c-47a2-9204-11702a2a147e.summary: What if an individual cannot ascertain all possible defeasers?
3f9dc3f1-0e8c-47a2-9204-11702a2a147e.content: {Consider a scenario where Mike concludes a meeting time from a reliable company calendar. However, unbeknownst to Mike, an unposted internal update changes it.}, {Even if the meeting occurs at the time Mike believed, lacking awareness of unanticipated defeasors undermines the claim of knowledge.}

779393e6-0ae4-458d-967b-0b03e5a613b6.summary: Does Defeasibility Theory sufficiently account for shared knowledge that loses context?
779393e6-0ae4-458d-967b-0b03e5a613b6.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a group believes a river is safe for swimming due to longstanding tradition, unaware of recent pollution.}, {Intuitively, the belief in true and justified context seems necessary for asserting collective knowledge, challenging Defeasibility Theory's simplicity.}

c051abf7-3725-4b26-8053-e6ff47306150.summary: Can persistence of belief without current validation hold as knowledge?
c051abf7-3725-4b26-8053-e6ff47306150.content: {There is a plausible principle that beliefs require ongoing accuracy checks especially when circumstances change.}, {Consider a scenario where Jason holds onto a fact about a mall layout unchanged for decades despite recent renovations unknown to him.}, {Maintaining this outdated view as knowledge even if partially accurate shows the insufficiency of persisting beliefs in volatile settings.}

9daf1dec-7a85-44bc-a7c9-79355ef8101f.summary: Is knowledge always dependent on belief?
9daf1dec-7a85-44bc-a7c9-79355ef8101f.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person acts in a way that suggests they have knowledge, even though they lack explicit belief. Intuitively, we would judge that this person has knowledge despite not having belief.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowledge can be implicit in actions. This principle suggests that belief is not a necessary component of knowledge.}

fbcca5bd-4b40-4c05-a383-cef572c82513.summary: Can knowledge exist independently of sensory experiences?
fbcca5bd-4b40-4c05-a383-cef572c82513.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person gains knowledge through mathematical reasoning alone. Intuitively, we would say that such knowledge is not based on sensory experiences.}, {It is implausible that abstract mathematical truths require sensory input to be known.}

c986cf73-71cf-4a11-8f8f-a0fdd9884dcc.summary: Are perceptions always required for knowledge?
c986cf73-71cf-4a11-8f8f-a0fdd9884dcc.content: {Consider a scenario where a blind person comes to know the layout of a room through verbal descriptions. Intuitively, we would judge that this person has knowledge of the room's layout without direct perception.}, {There is a plausible principle that verbal or conceptual understanding can lead to knowledge without direct sensory perception.}

5c36e36b-90d6-4279-b789-43ebc8f4583f.summary: Could abstract truths count as knowledge despite not being perceptions?
5c36e36b-90d6-4279-b789-43ebc8f4583f.content: {A person knows that the shortest distance between two points is a straight line through logical deduction. Intuitively, this knowledge is not a perception but an understanding of a geometric concept.}, {It is implausible that knowledge of geometric truths can only be considered knowledge if it is perceptual.}

2deeb947-7b26-4944-b269-74c5ecbca7dc.summary: Is belief necessary for all forms of knowledge?
2deeb947-7b26-4944-b269-74c5ecbca7dc.content: {Consider a scenario where a person computes the answer to a mathematical question but does not consciously believe it due to insecurity, yet answers correctly. Intuitively, we might still say they know the answer.}, {There is a plausible principle that knowledge sometimes occurs without explicit belief, particularly in domains requiring computation or expertise.}

a2f643a2-653b-47e1-ac3c-9eedfd77ff7c.summary: Can sensory experiences be misleading yet still result in knowledge?
a2f643a2-653b-47e1-ac3c-9eedfd77ff7c.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person sees a bent stick in water, a misleading perception due to light refraction, but correctly knows the stick is straight due to experience with similar scenarios. Intuitively, they have knowledge contrary to sensory perception.}, {It is implausible to say that knowledge always aligns with sensory perceptions when experience and context adjust our understanding.}

29155f63-8ba8-4561-8fd5-47de584c7831.summary: Are perceptions sufficient for establishing knowledge?
29155f63-8ba8-4561-8fd5-47de584c7831.content: {Consider a scenario where a person perceives an illusion, like a mirage, and believes there is water ahead. Intuitively, the perception does not result in true knowledge of water.}, {There is a plausible principle that perceptions can be deceptive and insufficient on their own for true knowledge.}

f1ecf936-965c-4b22-aa95-bc68afaa5338.summary: Does knowledge require more than just sensory experiences?
f1ecf936-965c-4b22-aa95-bc68afaa5338.content: {Suppose a person is able to predict weather changes through reasoning based on observed patterns rather than direct sensations. Intuitively, the knowledge goes beyond immediate sensory experiences.}, {It is implausible to say that all knowledge is tied to immediate sensory inputs when reasoning provides deeper understanding.}

0baafec0-cea2-4fe8-a1f8-1905ec1d6b38.summary: Can knowledge derived from memory challenge the dependence on immediate sensory experiences?
0baafec0-cea2-4fe8-a1f8-1905ec1d6b38.content: {Consider a scenario where a person accurately recounts historical events from detailed study and memory rather than present experiences. Intuitively, such knowledge is not based on current sensory experience.}, {There is a plausible principle that memory, as a source of knowledge, may not always be tied to direct sensory experience.}

222bc7a0-773f-4822-9815-3b5ebb3aff21.summary: Is it plausible that knowledge could be purely conceptual?
222bc7a0-773f-4822-9815-3b5ebb3aff21.content: {A case in which a philosopher understands moral principles conceptually without needing empirical evidence suggests knowledge of ethical truths can be non-perceptual.}, {There is a plausible principle that some kinds of knowledge, like moral knowledge, are not necessarily reliant on sensory experiences or perception.}

4a3e29b7-d3bb-4553-a656-6d67dd1d99aa.summary: Does the definition of knowledge rule out all false beliefs?
4a3e29b7-d3bb-4553-a656-6d67dd1d99aa.content: {It is plausible to define knowledge in a way that allows for some false beliefs under certain conditions.}, {Consider a scenario where a person has a justified, coherent belief system that is predominantly true with some falsehoods embedded due to misleading evidence. Intuitively, we might still consider this to be a case of knowledge in a broader, practical sense.}

835f3f9b-36ff-44fd-a2fb-226034a0daaa.summary: Is it possible for one to know something without necessarily believing it?
835f3f9b-36ff-44fd-a2fb-226034a0daaa.content: {Consider a scenario where a person, due to some psychological condition, recites facts accurately but does not personally believe them. Intuitively, we might judge that they have knowledge in terms of the factual content they convey.}, {A plausible principle is that knowledge can be attributed to individuals based on behavior and factual accuracy, without the necessity of personal belief.}

f1c938d8-d354-4c74-b18b-edec2eed35ba.summary: Can empirical sciences fully capture the normative dimension of epistemology?
f1c938d8-d354-4c74-b18b-edec2eed35ba.content: {It is implausible that empirical sciences can entirely account for the normative aspects of what one ought to believe or what justifies a belief.}, {Suppose an empirical study finds that most people form beliefs based on unreliable cognitive shortcuts. Normatively, we should still hold that some of those beliefs might not be justified, despite their empirical prevalence.}

7a7fdcd7-93d1-4939-9c22-c65469e5070d.summary: Does the requirement of truth in knowledge make knowledge impossible to achieve in principle?
7a7fdcd7-93d1-4939-9c22-c65469e5070d.content: {A scenario in which every account of truth we have access to is fallible, thus making the absolute realization of truth and hence knowledge practically impossible.}, {There is a plausible argument that requiring truth in a fallible human epistemic system sets an unattainably high criterion for what counts as knowledge.}

21702f22-a21a-49c3-9441-3fb70d79a6eb.summary: Are there instances where knowledge exists independently of contemporary empirical science?
